instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> odd symtoms
threads.message:
My <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> has 12.1V instead of 12.6V. The only noticeable thing that doesn't function properly is the power button. if pressed when the laptops on, it instantly restarts. When off it doesn't turn the machine on, you have to unplug the battery, plug in a charger and then hotplug the battery. 
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is good.
I have replaced the SMC with no change.

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> has 3v42 on it
Keyboard tested. 

Ive figured its not doing a full SMC reset when the power buttons pressed either, SMC reset circuitry has been ruled out. The only thing i can see as obvius damage is long screw damage into the board where the Fan screws in (on the webcam connector side of the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> odd symtoms
threads.message:
12.1V without battery connected??
For the SMC reset issue check corrosion around <CHIP>U5750</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> odd symtoms
threads.message: I seen this a few times on this board, always <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q8931</TRANSISTOR>. Pull the FET and check if its already burning a hole through the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> odd symtoms
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Gurmon, post: 26866"]I seen this a few times on this board, always <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q8931</TRANSISTOR>. Pull the FET and check if its already burning a hole through the board.[/QUOTE]

Holly Shit my power button functions after replacing those fets.

The fets i put on get pretty hot now so im not sure if they are safe to leave on there. Do They naturally run hot?

gobsmaked that replacing those fets restored my power button though, Good work!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> odd symtoms
threads.message: Those FETs have nothing to do with the original problem, use logic to figure out why. Also those FETs frying is because of bad soldering on the common problem child <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>.
